Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Emergent Quantum Confinement-Induced Properties of a New Class of Aromatic Ligand-Passivated Hybrid ITO Nanocrystals
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY
 
Nanocrystals (NCs) have inorganic core dimensions on the order of a billionth of a meter. It is challenging to assemble them into larger superstructures. Along these lines, this award, which is supported by the Solid State and Materials Chemistry program in the Division of Materials Research, addresses the forefront of modern nanoscience and nanotechnology-related research. Using polymers as solvents to synthesize ultrasmall tin-doped indium oxide (ITO) NCs this project targets a material with potential applications in fabrication of improved optoelectronic devices such as photovoltaics, light-emitting diodes, photodetectors, and photocatalytic solar fuel production. The project investigates how surface attachment of appropriately chosen organic molecules produces hybrid-ITO NCs (artificial molecules), and as a consequence alters the optoelectronic and electrochemical properties of the individual ITO NCs and their assemblies. Traditionally these properties are varied by changing the inorganic core size of NCs. Because of the different underlying mechanism to tune properties, the impact of this research is expected to be far-reaching in the context of new materials design, advancing molecular level understanding in nanoscience and materials chemistry, and economic expansion and sustainability. Additionally, this project provides multidisciplinary research training opportunities, including inorganic chemistry, materials science and nanotechnology, for graduate and undergraduate students. Through these activities the principle investigator fosters the next generation STEM educators and innovators.

TECHNICAL SUMMARY
 
Ligand-passivated nanocrystals (NCs) are of immense interest to chemists, physicists, and materials scientists, because NC-ligand interfacial electronic interactions and bonding greatly impact their chemical and physical properties. Through this Solid State and Materials Chemistry-funded project the principle investigator synthesizes and characterizes a new class of ultrasmall, quantum confined hybrid-ITO NCs. Functionalizing the NC core with uniquely designed aromatic ligands allows the researchers to manipulate the interaction and electronic coupling of interfacial energetic states between the inorganic (ITO core) and organic surface ligands. This leads to new structure-function relationships, which are fundamentally different from those previously characterized in traditional larger ITO NCs. Specific objectives of this project include: (1) experimentally characterizing the optoelectronic properties of this new class of hybrid-ITO NCs, both to understand the fundamental chemical and structural processes that exist at the NC-ligand interface and to control electronic coupling between individual energetic state of the NC and ligands, (2) correlating experimental spectroscopic data with computational models to predict the effects of the NC size and the electronic and/or chemical structure of surface ligands on optoelectronic properties, and (3) predictably assembling hybrid ITO-NCs into artificial solids and then measuring charge transfer and transport properties in the solid-state with the aim of understanding mechanisms controlling such phenomena. Taken together, results from this project are crucial in ultimately guiding the preparation of novel inorganic-organic hybrid nanomaterials to increase efficiency of solid-state optoelectronic devices and photocatalysts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was inspired by unique localized surface plasmon resonance (LSPR) properties of noble metal nanoparticles (NPs), and focuses on metal oxide NPs, which can be synthesized by using earth abundant elements such as indium, tungsten, tin and oxygen. An advantage of using earth abundant materials is that in the future nanomaterials for catalytic, photothermal, and photovoltaic applications will be cost efficient and easily scalable. Another advantage is that the LSPR properties of metal oxide-based nanomaterials can be tuned from visible to mid-infrared region of the solar spectrum that cannot be achieved via traditional noble metal nanoparticles. The project proposed to accomplish three objectives:  (1) Synthesize ultrasmall metal oxide NPs using colloidal methods; (2) Examine the electronic interaction at the ultrasmall NP-ligand interface to modulate band structures and optoelectronic propeties; and (3) Characterize electrochemical properties of ligand-passivated metal oxide NPs.

 

The first aim was accomplished by developing colloidal synthetic methods to prepare ultrasmall, 1.3, 1.5, and 1.7 nm diameter Sn-decorated indium oxide (In2O3) NPs by varying the reaction conditions. Importantly, our X-ray photoelectron spectroscopic analysis suggested that Sn was not part of the In2O3 NP, rather Sn4+ ions were ionically attached onto the surface of the NCs. A surprising discovery is that when the same experimental condition was applied to synthesize tungsten oxide (WO3) NPs, we observed the formation of atomically-thin, two-dimensional WO3-x nanoplatelets (NPLs). WO3-x NPLs displayed unprecedentedly large free electron density (Ne) of 3.95 X 1022 1022 cm-3. This is the highest Ne value reported for plasmonic metal oxide NPs, and thus our oxide-based NPs can be considered as quasi-metallic. By manipulating the reaction conditions, we were able to synthesize ~1.6 nm diameter WO3-x NPs, which display LSPR peak in the visible region. Next, the group has taken the initiative to determine the structural parameters that led to high Ne value of WO3-x NPLs. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy and electron paramagnetic resonance spectroscopy analyses suggested that surface chemistry is the most prevalent factor in achieving this unprecedentedly high Ne value and the relevant LSPR and electrochemical properties of plasmonic WO3-x NPLs.

 

The WO3-x NPLs were used as a heterogeneous catalyst for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) that showed excellent catalytic efficiency with a low overpotential, as similar to the commercially available noble metal based catalyst (Pt/C). It was determined that (1) a higher Ne value promoted the HER reaction more efficiently and (2) the surface ligand chemistry significantly controlled the overpotential of HER reactions.

 

The broader impact of the project was spread throughout the community. Female and underrepresented minority undergraduate students through NSF-led program learned how to synthesize efficient nanomaterials for renewable energy applications. In addition, high school students through American Chemical Society-SEED program gained important research experience in synthesizing and analyzing nanomaterials, and fabricating electrode materials for electro-catalytic applications. The group meeting and collaboration between students, theoretician, and scientists from the national laboratory has enhanced the training and perspective of all who participated. Results were also incorporated into college level classes on optoelectronic and electrochemical properties of nanomaterials.  Results have been disseminated through peer-reviewed publications and conference presentations.
